description.text: Modified for a Fellow Redditor!

A mount for the APM2 Purple to mount where a KKBoard/HobbyKing board was before.
T adapter works for + mode, Y+X works for both.

Requires: 8 nylon nuts, 4 nylon standoffs (Mostly reused from previous mount) Directions:
  • Print board
  • Mount to nylon standoffs to the board where the APM is to connect
  • Mount adapter plate to the quad
  • Mount the APM to the adapter plate
  • ???
  • Profit! Ok, fly your quad!

When I'm using 8020 25 series aluminum extrusions, manufacturer's t nuts are very expensive, so I got some cheap t nut for 20 series extrusions. But those nuts are small to 25 series slots. Moreover I wanted to fix the position of the t nuts, but anchoring t nuts are so more expensive. This is why I quickly made these t nut holder for cheap solution to anchoring t nuts inside 8020 25 series aluminum extrusion.

The outer dimension is tightly fit to 25 series slots, so it will stay where you push into.

Enjoy!

title: Robo C2 or R2 Gantry Alignment Tool

description.text:
Print 4 of these for aligning Robo R2 and Robo C2 to the gantry. Great for keeping the gantry square when performing maintenance, or realignment from gantry movement. Best way to align and square the gantry on both the C2 and R2 is to loosen the X and Y movement pulleys in the 4 corners, then apply the gantry alignment tools, 2 on the x axis, 2 on the y axis, then re-tighten down the pulleys.

For a better step-by-step tutorial, please follow this article: https://help.robo3d.com/hc/en-us/articles/115001792512

title: QIDI Tech I Dual Fan Duct (from FB group)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is not my design. It is from the QIDI 3D FB group, originally designed by Tommy Johnson. It can be printed without support. Depending on your slicer settings, may need some cleaning up. The scuff marks in the picture are from light sanding. It was printed with ABS at 230*C/100*C, 0% fan, 60mm/s.

Tommy's Remarks:

Bottom flat on table, no netfab required , do recommend supports at fan inlet bottom side top should bridge fine
Used 4 layers /tops /bottom and 30% infill
Been in use on my printers for months printed in abs ,and on a friend of mine as well and he used petg

Log:
v3 - From Tommy Johnson. Can be reoriented and printed as is.
v3.1 - Reoriented model, repaired with NetFabb (not sure if necessary).

title: Wood Utensil Organizer Shim
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Let's keep this simple (Pro Tip from the Future - I can never keep things simple):

I have a utensil drawer organizer - two of them, actually. They're made of wood, and they fit perfectly in my two kitchen drawers when fully expanded. You can see that they are well-loved. Also, this style of drawer organizer is fairly popular. I'm posting this Thing, in the hope that folks with a similar need, can use my fabulous design. I say fabulous, because whenever I add fillets, and curves, and tapered extrusion, I feel like Jony Ive - without the hundreds of millions of dollars.

But yes, design is good. Good design is fun.

So what need does this fill? Well, that's easy: the stupid organizer kept contracting in the drawer, so it didn't look perfect. I needed to put something in there to keep it open. At first I thought "dowel!" But I'm crap with saws and wood. Then I thought "3D printer!" So I grabbed my digital calipers and measured the inside of the expanding/contracting side at 84mm in one drawer and 82mm in the other. I wanted something dowel-like, so I grabbed a pen. A standard Bic pen was too thin, diameter wise, so I chose the cap-end, which was about 10mm. Perfect!

At first, I thought I was going to put these shims into the bottom, front and back. And that would have worked (if it weren't for you meddling kids!), but then I realized that the shims fit perfectly into the grooves in the front and back. Because of the slight taper, and the 3D printing layer lines, these just snap into place and have the perfect amount of resistance/friction to stay put.

If you like this shim, and want to have it made up in a different size, just let me know. There's the "height" (currently 10mm), the "width" (10mm), and the "length" (82mm and 84mm). These dimensions should be fairly obvious. Leave a comment, let me know what you'd like, and I'll work one up for you.

If you can think of a way that I can improve this shim, please let me know!

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

These just print. Standard leveling, and printing rules for items with smaller footprints. I use PVA (purple school glue sticks) on my glass bed and each set came out perfect.

Easy Cleanup

Because you want a little bit of friction if you're sliding this into a groove, you shouldn't have to sand anything down. It should "just work," assuming you have the right dimensions. If you don't have the correct dimensions, please use digital calipers to let me know exactly what you need for your application.

Fusion 360, Netfabb 2017 and Simplify3D

Once again, I used Fusion 360 to design this shim. It's simple but also fun and elegant design. I started with a rectangle, and made two, huge circles on the sides, to cut out the curves. I then built up a tapered extrusion, and created a varying fillets for the top and bottom. All of this was done with procedural modeling and functions/variables, so I can go in and create new versions quickly and easily.

I can adjust the LxWxH, the fillets (more or less curvy), and also the cut-outs on the side (more or less curvy, depending on the size of the circles). The design is symmetrical from side to side, but not from top-to-bottom due to the intentional tapering.

I always clean things up in Netfabb 2017, but this didn't need any actual clean-up.

Lastly, I used Simplify3D to slice and create the output files, which I then transferred to the printer via a Toshiba FlashAir SD card, over wireless.

title: A gun Inspired by Legends of Tomorrow - Rip's Gun
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
9/28 - corrected scale of frame now v2

I was inspired to build this gun after seeing it on the series Legends of Tomorrow.

I have designed all the prices so that very little glue is required.

The Chamber is actually 3 pieces. A dark/black outer chamber, a translucent inner chamber and cap. This way you can add an LED or two.

Please note: The Chamber does not revolve. It is designed to lineup with barrel and lock in place.

I recommend printing the barrel and chamber pin at 50% fill for added strength.

I notice after printing the holes in the grips do not line up exactly with the frame. I am going to fill them with a plug that looks like a rivet anyway. You may wish to do the same.

Also, I recommend spray paint, the brush paint does not look so good. Or print in black like I will for the next one to tweak issues.

You may need to sand the trigger and hammer pin a bit, this is by design.

Download print and enjoy. Feedback is welcome

If don't have access to a printer, I can print and mail it to you. Just reach out to me on ETSY or below
www.pixi3d.com

Cheers

remixed_from.author: kb0nly
remixed_from.title: 3D Printer Shutdown Timer, Auto Off Switch

description.text:
This is not a remix of the referenced Shutdown Timer Thing, but rather just the cover for the FRM01 timer board. While I like the Shutdown Thing, the thought of having the timer, even inside the printer enclosure, with exposed 110V terminals sounded like a bad idea. So this Thing adds terminal covers to the FRM01 timer enclosure used there.

While I wasn't planning to rework anything else, the enclosure was also too tight for my FRM01, and the holes didn't match very well, so I reworked those a bit too. I suspect the timers may come from several Chinese manufacturers, so it's possible that the hole positions vary between them.

I also added some mounting holes inside the bottom cover, so that the timer could be mounted on a surface with screws. Those holes are positioned so that the screw heads are beneath a low-voltage flat surface of the timer board; an added interference block prevents the timer board from being inserted in a reversed position, which would place high voltage pins near the screw heads.

comments.text: Nice job!  Thats why i also made the more enclosed cover that goes over the screw terminals as well, but your design makes a nice wiring channel to hide the wires also!  One comment though, theres no high voltage at this device, 24v comes in and goes out, it shouldn't be switching the 110v.
comments.author: kb0nly

comments.text: Oh right, it would normally be 24V.  But in my case I have a switching supply built into the base of my Replicator, and when I do the auto-off, it will need to switch the 110.  I can't just switch the 24 because I also have 110V chamber heaters that have to be turned off too.
comments.author: kb0nly

comments.text: Ahh i see.  I was thinking of one of the chinese models with a power supply in the bottom but you could still switch the 24v, but in your case with the heaters that makes perfect sense.  Even with the 24v on the terminals a cover isn't a bad idea, makes it look cleaner, especially if you run the wires out the back or whatever surface the timer is mounted to.  Good design on the covers, i like em so much i will probably print some for my printers to tidy up the wiring... LOL
comments.author: garyacrowellsr

remixed_from.author: Elzariant
remixed_from.title: Tevo Black Widow - Modular X Carriage

description.text:
This is a compact LA03-2500 2500mW laser mount designed to be compatible with Elzariant's x-carriage system.

The item and technical drawings can be found here: https://www.banggood.com/445nm-2_5W-2500mW-Blue-Laser-Module-With-Heatsink-For-DIY-Laser-Cutter-Engraver-p-993521.html.

Elzariant's original design can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1829292/#comments

The laser can be screwed into the mount using up to seven M3 8mm screws (optimal) or M3 10mm screws (may require a washer). I designed in vented holes into the mount to decrease material issue, decrease ABS warping, and assist with cooling of the part. The mount itself can then be slid onto the mounting rail. Since the part is not loaded heavily and a little sliding would not affect laser engraving quality, the mount does not have to be screwed down to the mother plate.

The mount comes in two variants, vented back and closed back. The closed back version is there so you can print the part more cleanly. On the first try with ABS, my vented back print was not perfectly clean, but it still mounted fine. However, I would just go with the closed-back version; it will be a lot easier to print and only marginally worse thermally.

description.text:
This compact pill box will store 31 days worth of pills. Just twist the cover open until you find your next pill. Day-of-the-week markers on the end let you know if you've missed a day. The cover can be locked closed to prevent accidental opening, and there is also a hollow core for bulk pill storage.

UPDATE: I've reworked some of the overhangs so that it now prints and operates much more smoothly

Printer:

UDIO

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The parts print without support, but the spiral ridge on the box will have a somewhat lumpy surface. This can be sanded or worked smooth with the cover.

The box is designed for fairly small pills (<10mm). You should be able to scale it up somewhat for larger pills.

After printing, screw the cover onto the body and work back & forth with a little force to smooth out the operation. Then snap the sliding dove-tail locking piece into place as shown.

To fill, open the cover to the last position and then start filling each position through the window in the cover. Spare pills can be stored in the hollow core. To get your pills, hold the cover with the window facing up and then unscrew the body until you see your next pill.

A 3d Printable Ergodox case.

Printer:

Maker Select V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

You will want to use supports on the bottom segments to allow the screw holes and indents for the feet to print properly. The tops and Plates do not need any support. Print everything with the flat surface down.
PLA would be the best option to avoid warping as the parts are quite large.
Filling and sanding will provide the best look and some parts may need to be sanded to fit together properly.

NOTE:
To ensure that the plate comes out the proper thickness you should do the first layer at .3mm and the rest at .2mm. There are chamfers in place to avoid issues with "elephant foot" in the switch holes but it might not hurt to clean them up with a needle file.

NOTE 2:
It can be printed on a maker select v2, you just need to go into the epprom with repetier host or similar and change the y max to ~215mm to provide enough room, It will get close to the edge but it will fit.

To complete the assembly you will need some M3 threaded brass inserts, I recommend these as others may be to large:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01IYWTCWW/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
16 m3x6mm bolt socket head screws
10 self adhesive rubber feet
And the necessary components for an ergodox. PCB, diodes, switches, ect.

Simply insert the threaded inserts into the holes in the top sections using a soldering iron to melt them in, you may want to insert them a bit further than flush to insure they stay secure.

Use the plate as normal, you may have to sand it to get it to fit together nicely.

Screw it together and then attach the feet.

NOTE:
TO resolve wobble, one of the feet may need to be attached with hot glue. Just put a blob under one of the corner feet and then place it gently on a flat surface making sure it sits level. The glue will act as a spacer and lift the foot to level the keyboard and remove any wobble.
A lot of trail and error, and about 2 KG of wasted filament on prototypes.

description.text:
I created this hopper for the filastruder V2, as i was having too many problems using it vertically that i reconfigured for horizontal operation.

The Hopper extension and lid I drew up in Fusion 360, and used the window idea from thingi https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:277996, I used the hopper attachement for horizontal operation from thingi https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:439909 i put a compatible thread into this with thingi https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:157541 and to give the hopper a base I flattened off the top of the this thingi https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:89073, to produce my new hopper design for the filastruder v2 it holds approx 1kg of pellets, and has good flow into the extruder.

If i get around to it, if I put a thread into the other chutes from thingi https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:439909 this hopper can be used in the filastruder in other orientations.

Update 24/12/17

I adjusted the hopper bracket to have a 25deg tilt on it as i run my filastruder now with a 25deg downward tilt, i found this to be a good angle for filament extrusion, and if you look in the photo 25deg is coming up around the maximum tilt available before i have to extend the bracket to allow it to clear the main body of the filastruder. I also put a locating collar on the bracket to ensure it stays in the right position.

title: Folding travel coat hanger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Inspired by an existing design - my 3d printable version of a folding travel coat hanger.

Just what you need when travelling. Light enough to pack in your case.
Particularly useful if you want to rinse out clothes when you are away or just hang stuff up.

2 configuration options for children or adult clothes.
Also includes a belt, tie, dress, light weight trousers hanging ability.

https://youtu.be/OOydxydYYmg

Enjoy!

UPDATE:
22/09/17
Added a v2 set - different hinge design which may suit some printers better.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

50% or higher

Notes:

I've printed this version in standard PLA and its does seem stable, but I'll see longterm how the pivot joints hold up?
ABS, Nylon or other more stable materials may be more appropriate?.
The tolerance of the clip fit pivots are going to test the set up of your printer to the max!
Over extrude and the parts won't 'clip' together.
Under extrude and it'll all be too loose!

Print 2 x parts:
Folding_coat_hanger_E.stl
Folding_coat_hanger_M.stl (supports needed)

The updated files of v2 have a peg and hole joint design. These joints should be firmly, but carefully 'wiggled' together until the peg clips into the hole - support the walls of the parts as you go.

description.text:
The original laser attachment that the Trinus comes with is way too off for proper homing at the edge of the build area. This mount allows a sideways movement to adjust the homing easily as needed. Works great with svgTrinusifier!

Depending on the layer adhesion of the filament and settings you use, I suggest being careful about how much you tighten the knobs. Overtightening could snap the whole mount part off.

description.text:
DEBUTING AT THE SEATTLE MINI MAKER FAIRE 2017, IT'S THE DESKTOP GUARDIAN KIT FROM MyOpen3D!

The Desktop Guardian is a basic Arduino kit that assembles into a trusty robot sidekick that will vigilantly stand watch over a small room, all while introducing builders to basic concepts in electronics, Arduino hardware and programming, and the fundamentals of sonar via an ultrasonic sensor. This kit is intended for children (aged 10+) and adults of all skill levels. We encourage all builders to tinker with the hardware design and Arduino sketch to adjust or broaden the Guardian’s basic functionality.

If you need assistance in assembly or if you would like help modify and/or change its functionality—particularly if you are located in the Seattle, Washington area—MyOpen3D encourages you to attend one of our workshops based on this kit! Please contact us to find dates for existing workshops or to schedule your own!

Once you've assembled the Guardian, be sure to check out this video narrated by MyOpen3D founder and lead designer, Alex Cheker, to get it up and running in no time: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D4XuGq49mvA

Also, be sure to follow us for more fun maker-y videos on 3D printing, CNC milling, basic electronics and engineering!

https://www.myopen3D.com

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this at a lower Z resolution just to make the rounded parts smoother so I did not have to worry about cleaning up the part.  I used 0.08mm and PCTG for the print in the pictures.  Where this part is inserted it is normally cool to the touch while printing.  PETG, ABS would all be fine.  PLA at this stage is untested so if users can report back what they have tried it would be great.  Being close to the heater block I would think the PLA could get soft and possibly deform.  Essentium PCTG has been fine at 260C prints.

description.text: This part fits directly into the vacant hole for the second extruder in the Robo R2, and it helps smooth out the airflow from the tiny fan and around the hexagon extruder heatsink.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

C2 R2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.08mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

This part fits directly into the hole for the second extruder that is not supplied with the Robo R2, and it helps smooth out the airflow from the tiny fan and around the hexagon extruder. Some users were seeing a heat creep type issue with certain brands of filament. Hopefully, this can help push more air over the extruder heatsink.

In testing the difference in airflow is noticeable and can now be felt on both sides of the heatsink. Without this, the air would tend to hit one side of the heatsink and you could feel more air being pushed directly down and out.

I printed this at a lower Z resolution just to make the rounded parts smoother so I did not have to worry about cleaning up the part. I used 0.08mm and PCTG for the print in the pictures. Where this part is inserted it is normally cool to the touch while printing. PETG, ABS would all be fine. PLA at this stage is untested so if users can report back what they have tried it would be great. Being close to the heater block I would think the PLA could get soft and possibly deform. Essentium PCTG has been fine at 260C prints.
Autodesk Fusion 360

author: JoPri

description.text:
During the summer months, I like to hang a blanket, a sheet, or a curtain if you will, in the doorway of our living room so that I can keep the cold, air conditioned air in the room without heat from the kitchen battling the window mounted air conditioner. The idea is to save money on our electricity bill as well as keeping the living room cooler than the rest of the house.

This hook allows me to pull back the curtain and hang it to the side by mounting it on top of the doorway frame with a single "brad" (small nail).

As always, if you make one, all I ask is that you please share a photo or at least comment on how it worked for you!

print_settings.Notes:: make sure your printer has pretty tight tolerances, the arms have less then a millimeter clearance,  You can change this in the code but not in the customiser.
print_settings.Infill:: 20% if you want it to float

description.text:
This was inspired by this design
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:863534

I wanted to make a modular design that was customisable and here is what i came up with.
This is not as flexible as i would like but it was a great exercise in parametric grid design .
Any openscad people can just replace the base module with whatever shape they want and they will be linked.

I have three different types of tops for different scrubbing surfaces. A smooth one, a bumpy one and a ridged one. You can choose any or all of them to be placed in a grid of your specifications.

Have fun and hack away at the code.
Let me know if you want any improvements or modifications.
//* Update **//
I updated the rides to print more clearly and adjusted the loops to have a base tolerance that should print without fusing the modules

title: 4th Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Pro Model - READ UPDATE!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATE!

This design has been superseded by my new Pro 2 Model 4th Axis Stabilizer which produces at least 30% smoother footage.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2689804

There's also a similarly smooth Compact Pro version made for phone and action cam gimbals here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2672749

My original gimbal stabilizer does a great job but I wanted to make it take even better silky smooth shots as well as being more Pro friendly. Both myself and others wanted more features to adapt better to the variable camera rigs and shots that we have to contend with on shoots. They needed attachment points for gear such as field monitors, audio recorders and compact LED lights. They wanted tool-less adjustment for on-the-go changes as well as attachment points for load bearing harnesses such as the ‘Easyrig’ so they could film all day in comfort.

I made a great showcase video here:-
https://youtu.be/AZvPQ1J-3NM

I've also made a DIY video here:-
https://youtu.be/Hnn4hXLNH0I

UPDATE: The DIY video and full instructions is now added! Sorry it took a while... been swamped with orders for this stabilizer :D There's a slight possibility this model may only be available for a limited time... still working that out but in the meantime download away :)

UPDATE2 I've just updated the Spring Adjust parts to take a captured nut in the base that is mainly designed for the NEW! pro stabilizer stands! You could also use the nut to attach something else too. I've also updated the Gimbal Support to V3. I've still kept the previous version in case anyone prefers that. V3 has been changed so that the top mounting surface is flat so that quick release plates can be more easily mounted. It also has two more captured nuts but this time on the top side.

UPDATE3 I've just added a mount for the Zhiyun remote control handlebar mount so you can control your Zhiyun gimbal without taking your hand off the handle! Enjoy!

So then I went back to the drawing board and after many more more prototypes and some very thorough testing I’m now super happy with the results! Not only does it reduce 4th axis motion but I also find it reduces some of the 5th & 6th axis motion too. I’m sure you’ll agree it takes Gimbal cinematography to that next level!

Shots are smooth and flowing and not only can you imitate crane , dolly and pan shots with it you can also combine these techniques into fluid shots that have that filmic look. I’m definitely a very amateur camera operator with a dodgy knee and even I can get great shots with ease… imagine what you could do!

This Pro Model has some newly tweaked geometries and some design improvements so you will get even smoother results. It even rivals the quality of stabilizer systems worth tens of thousands.

The Original’s fixed fluid dampening has now been upgraded in the Pro Model to fully adjustable variable dampening. There’s dual independent dampening indicators so you can perfectly dial it in for anything from silky smooth gentle motion through to maximum dampening when you're shooting those ‘running like crazy to keep up with your talent’ kinds of shots.

Shooting situations can change quickly and you need to keep up. The tool-less design of the Pro model helps you quickly make changes so you're ready in seconds.

The Pro model can place the gimbal at 4 different shooting heights thanks to its 200 degree rosette adjustable handles and upright and inverted attachment wheels.
You can go from a high shot and with one free hand you can quickly change to an eye level shot. Then with the attachment wheels you can invert your gimbal for a ground shot for those low to the ground shots. And finally invert the handles to a medium-low shot.

The Pro model has 6 of the ¼ - 20 attachment points;

  • With the two attachment wheel bolts
  • Two front facing nuts ideal for audio or lighting
  • Two handle nuts that can be used with a ‘Easyrig’ load carrier or maybe move your audio or lighting there too.
    To further control the centre of gravity you can use a video quick release plate to counterbalance your gimbal by sliding it back and forth

Well, if you’ve come this far you know I’m super excited about this new Pro Model 4th Axis Gimbal Stabiliser and I’m really itching to see what you guys film with it!

You can check out my other designs here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/ScottyMakesStuff/designs

You can see all my videos on my YouTube Channel, ScottyMakesStuff here:-
https://www.youtube.com/c/ScottyMakesStuff
https://twitter.com/ScottyMakesStuf
https://www.instagram.com/scottymakesstuff/

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Notes:

To start, there are a lot of parts and each has specific instruction listed below. I suggest printing models in the orientation supplied. As this is a model that uses close tolerances your printer will have to be calibrated correctly or you'll have problems.

I use the triangular infill as it's good and strong. With my Original Prusa MK2S running at normal speeds and Simplify3D slicing I find all parts need little to no post printing work and fit perfectly... don't rush it! I print mine in an improved PLA. This is good to 55C (130F) degrees so don't leave it in a car on a very hot day... but the same should be said of any camera equipment so I think improved PLA will be best for 95% of you. You can try other filaments such as PETG, ABS or PC but you'd want to have a special set up and be a pro at getting those to work flawlessly.

4thAxis_GimbalSupport_V3 or older 4thAxis_GimbalSupport_45mm_V2

Settings: 0.20mm layers, 3 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports, has two captured nuts

It's important to print the rosettes at a fine layer height as these will mesh together and as such needs to be as accurate as possible. I printed mine at 0.10mm. Better still, if your slicer can print variable layer heights then you can print fine layers where it's needed and then speed up your prints significantly.

The gimbal support and the two handles have captured bolts that will need to be inserted during the print. You can make sure you're there to pause the print and drop the nuts in or you could get a little funky with some gcode to stop the print for you. I typically use the free notepad++ to add some simple code to the gcode file just right before the covering layer is printed. Your printer will wait at this point until you hit resume. This is some example code (Note: please add X & Y coordinates to suit your print so that the print head gets out of the way for you) ;
; layer (whatever layer your print comes to), Z = 9.6 (depending on your print layer height the handle will need to be about this height when it stops)
; Add Nuts
M117 Add the nuts Scotty ; displays the message on your printer
G1 X(add your X coord here) Y(add your Y coord here) F8000 ; move out of way - you will need to work yours out relative to your print
M72 @pause ; pauses and plays the pause tune
M0
; inner perimeter

4thAxis_SpringAdjust_R_V5 & 4thAxis_SpringAdjust_L_V5

Settings: 0.08mm - 0.25mm layers (see below), 4 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports

It's important to print the rosettes at a fine layer height as these will mesh together and as such needs to be as accurate as possible. I printed mine at 0.10mm. Better still, if your slicer can print variable layer heights then you can print fine layers where it's needed and then speed up your prints significantly. In that case I'd suggest printing all but the rosette at 0.20mm to 0.30mm and printing just the rosette at 0.08mm.

4thAxis_Handle_V2.stl

Settings: 0.15 - 0.3mm layers (see below), 3 to 4 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports, has a captured nut in each handle base

See above Gimbal Support advice for dealing with the captured nuts)
There's two of these to print. I print mine at 0.30mm and when I get to 15mm below the rosette I change from 3 perimeters to 4 and I also change the layer height to 0.15mm

SpringKnob, GimbalScrewKnob, DampeningKnob & HandleKnob

Settings: 0.15 to 0.20 mm layers , 3 perimeters, 25% fill, No Supports

TopArm_L_V3, TopArm_R_V3, BottomArm_L_V3, BottomArm_R_V3

Settings: 0.15 to 0.20 mm layers , 3 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports

DamperDynamicSide & DamperStaticSide

Settings: 0.15 to 0.20 mm layers , 3 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports

List of non-printing parts

Note: All fiitings are for 1/4 - 20 threaded

  • 2 x steel washers
  • 14 x thin brass washers
  • 10 x Nylock nuts
  • 8 x hex nuts
  • 2 x extension springss
    • For Payload (Camera/Gimbal/extras) weight of 1kg to 3Kg use http://www.centuryspring.com/extension-spring-651.html
      I'm currently investigating some springs for slightly heavier loads and will report back once they've been tested.
  • 2 x small compression springs (optional)
  • 2 x 1 1/2 inch bolts - handles
  • 2 x 3/4 inch bolts - gimbal attachment wheels
  • 4 x 3 inch bolts
  • 6 x 2 1/2 inch bolts
  • 2 x wingnuts
  • Lithium grease or similar
  • syringe for injecting grease (3 -10 ml size)
  • two part epoxy glue (Araldite)

comments.text: Finally finished mine...well almost. After a few mods I'll be posting a Make. Great work and thanks again! Just a few thoughts so far: 1) It seems the centre of gravity is very high with the gimbal attached in this fashion. Have you had any thoughts about the advantages/disadvantages of that? I'm currently designing a center section that will clamp to the gimbal a little further up the hand grip/battery compartment to see if that helps things.  2) This one is obvious but maybe something to be aware for anyone using this type of device: the suspension still offloads some of the forces into your arms in the sense that the distance between the handles can affect the force pushing back against the system. So make sure to keep things loose and don't pull apart/squeeze together. You're arms are sort of part of the dampening system as well and can defeat the absorption if you're not careful.
comments.author: emkaybot

comments.text:
Hi Marc, and thanks! Can't wait to see your modded make!
With the gimbal properly balanced and mounted to the stabilizer in the eye-line position I don't have any issues with the centre of gravity. The handles in the upright position further centres the centre of gravity too. Even with the handles pointing down (high position) I don't experience any serious lack of control from forward or backward rotation but YMMV. The under-slung gimbal in the low and ground level positions are the easiest to shoot but only useful if that suits the shot.
Yes, soft hands are a must! I'm going to be making some short instructional videos when I get a chance... I've been selling these to people without printers and haven't had time to do anything else these last few weeks... Though it's a good problem to have :-)

description.text:
English

Support T for m4 nuts, compatible with 20 x 20 mm profile. The piece has 0.5mm of clearance for nut fitting and for fitting in the profile. Remember to calculate the retraction effect of the filament used to print the part.

Português

Suporte T para porcas m4, compatível com perfil de 20 x 20 mm. A peça tem 0,5mm de folga para encaixe da porca e para encaixe no perfil. Lembre-se de calcular o efeito de retração do filamento utilizado para impressão da peça.

3d modeling

English

The piece was modeled in the Sketchup program. The purpose of this part is to replace commercial T-shaped nuts with printed parts that support single M5 nuts (commonly found in any hardware store). The intention of this piece is not to cheapen the product, but to create a solution alternative to the lack of it.

A peça foi modelada no programa Sketchup. description.text:
When I first bought a MKS Sbase, I looked here on Thingiverse to see if there were any good, solid mounts for 20x20mm aluminum extrusion. None of existing mounts satisfied my requirements, so it was time to design my own! The result is what you see here. This mount is intended to fit into the corner where two of the extrusions meet - see the picture of the base of my DIY Ultimaker2 for an example.

This mount uses M3 hex nuts inserted from the bottom to thread the M3 screws (M3x12 or M3x14... I can't remember exactly...) into, eliminating the possibility of stripping out plastic threads. The 6mm plate thickness ensures that the mount is very stiff, essentially eliminating any deflection.

Print one out and let me know what you think!

Yes

I recommend ~20%

If you've got good cooling, you can probably get away without the supports. I forgot to enable the supports when I printed mine, and the small (1mm) 90 degree overhangs that fit into the extrusion slots still turned out great.

title: Aluminum Window Screen Frame Mitered Corner Connector

description.text:
This is an internal corner connector for mitered aluminum window screen frames.
This is for 3/4" x 5/16" (external) aluminum frame. There are many styles of frame so please view the pictures to compare the shape with yours. I printed it in ABS with a 0.6 mm nozzle at 0.2 mm layer and 20% infill and it is quite strong. The grey part pictured is what this part replaces. The semi-circular groves are simply to reduce surface area to lessen friction and binding. To assemble it is best to stand the part upright on a hard flat surface and push the frame down onto the part. Trying to push the part into the frame may break the part, bend the frame, or run the frame through you hand.

Use at your own risk. If this causes your house to implode, explode, or fractures the space-time continuum I'm not responsible. If it brings peace on Earth, contact with aliens, communication with animals, or other good things I'll take all the credit.

title: Customizable Pipette Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a pipette holder that I made for holding 10 10 ml pipettes. There are slots in the bottom to allow any remaining moisture to drain. These slots also help with air flow to ensure the pipettes can dry out.

I provided the fusion 360 file so that you can simply import an stl file and extrude whatever logo or image you like. The picture shown is a pipette holder with my hub's insignia, but the STL file included is only a blank slate.

I designed this to print without need for any support. The pencil holder should be printed with the two slots on the print bed. Simply print the holder and 4 feet, and then glue the feet to the main body of the pipette holder. I personally just use some 3M adhesive for my parts, but there are several other adhesives that will work just as well. If you print using ABS you can coat the feet and the locations you intend to attach them to on the base with acetone to make them bond.

I find that the easiest way to create my logo STL file is to trace the logo or image I want in Inkscape and them import the resulting STL after the picture has been removed into my modeling software. I typically just find a font that's close enough to whatever is used in the logo for the text and convert it to paths to save time.

remixed_from.title: Rick's Portal Gun from Rick and Morty

title: Rick and Morty portal gun stand brackets

description.text: Shown is my 'remix' of ricks portal gun. Its not a remix but adding a fairly easy set of brackets and cross member to mount your portal gun to a block of biological material. The screws you should use are #6 flat or oval head. The ones I used are chromium coated gives it a nice gunmetal look. The brackets are forgiving so you will have a little wiggle room. The wooden block I used is 214mmx92mm. From the right side of the block the right edge of the right bracket is 12mm from the edge. The right edge of the left hand bracket is 119mm from the right side of the block. This gave me good centering and balance to the display.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

1.31

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I printed these all flat on the bed, low infill needed and no supports. Filament I used was Hatchbox Carbon Fiber Pla.

Post-processing

On the portal gun I did a LOT of post processing. I sanded the surfaces of the portal gun flat and glued the pieces together. Once it was dry it was a lot of sanding. I used the Bondo filler putty to fill the layer lines and it worked great, and sanded well. After doing this over and over when I was satisfied I painted with a filler primer and sanded more. Finish coat was matte rustoleum with sanding to 2000 grit between coats!

title: Star Realms Box with cut outs

description.text:
This is a remake of a design submitted by erik_uy: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2106463

I printed his version and was having an issue getting the lid to go on the caddy, even after sanding. I decided to add some semi-circles around the 4 edges for better grip.

I also just made a simple divider so I can keep both my core decks separated easier. If you sleeve your cards this probably will not fit.

NOTE: I printed everything at 100% scale, EXCEPT for the lid. I had better luck printing the lid at 100.25%. Now the lid stay on the caddy and doesn't jiggle, but is easy to remove. This could very well be because of my printer, and/or my filament, and this may not work for you personally. But that scale worked best for me.

From erik_uy's post:
"
A fully custom-made card caddy for Star Realms.

Designed for use with unsleeved cards from the following sets:

Core Set
Colony Wars Expansion
Crisis Expansion Complete Set
United Expansion Complete Set
Compartments from front to back are for:

Player starter decks x4 (Vipers, Scouts, Life Counters)
Explorers
Main Deck
Missions
Instruction Cards/Booklets
I'll update the design if I ever get a hold of the expansions sets I don't have, but this is it for now.

Happy gaming!

--erik
"

This was created for my mobile systems exam at university of applied science in Lemgo, Germany. This app can visualize GCode (created with Slic3r) for RepRap and Makerbot 3D printers. It can also color code the Gcode when you enable the verbose Gcode in Slic3r. See it in Action:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IWZBLxS9sF8 Update (06.02.2013):
I now have a Lenovo IdeaTab with Android 4.0.3. I tried my GCodeViewer and the app crashes all the time. I will try to update the app to work with more devices. I hope I find some time between my exams and my bachelor thesis to work on this project again. :)

Download the App and install it on your Android phone. You can find the latest version here: https://bitbucket.org/bifi5590/android-gcode-viewer Still need to rework the 3D Visualization but my Bachelor Thesis is consuming most of my free time at the moment. Android 2.2 or newer is required. The app works on:
Samsung Galaxy GT551
HTC Desire Z
HTC Evo 4G and Cyanogen 7.2 The 3D visualization works not on:
Motorola Milestone
Samsung Galaxy S2 This is maybe because of OpenGL ES 1.1 or its something with GL_LINE_STRIP. I will publish the source code as soon as I have the results of my exam.

title: DJI Spark Slide-On Protection Cover / Minimal Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
DJI Spark Slide-On Protection Cover / Minimal Case - Propeller Protection For DJI Spark

This propeller cover slides and locks into place. I used a 2.5mm diameter elastic cord but you can simply use a rubber band.

Demo video: https://youtu.be/TaXcvOx1NaQ

I've been wanting to just toss my Spark into my bag without a bulky case and not worry about damaging the drone. The most fragile parts of the drone is the camera gimbal and propellers. This serves as a bare-minimum protection for the clever little DJI Spark.

Comes with 2 options, a snap-on guard that snaps onto the Spark's body or just a simple eyelet. Designed to be printed without supports.

I've spent many hours creating and fine tuning this design, please leave a "like" if you like and share your prints! I would love to see them! :-)

This is still a work-in-progress. Final version will include a camera mount and belt clip. Please follow me to get updates!

description.text:
The short: Box for holding desiccant.

The Long: I saw somewhere, don't remember where, a picture of someone's enclosure with an acryclic box on top covering the spool of filament. Since summer started I've been fighting humidity in my printer room constantly. This led me to buy a bunch of desiccant, and a pail, and bags, and humidity gauges, and a dehumidifier. Needless to say the filament was staying drier. The only PIA was after each printer I needed to remove the filament and store it away. In comes the acrlylic box. It took awhile to find a place to purchase one that didn't cost an arm and a leg. I'd seen them in the UK for 10 pounds, so I didn't think paying 80$ was reasonable. Now I just needed to keep it dry in the new display box. That's what this is model is for. It's a box to store the desiccant that I bought in bulk. It's designed to fit just right underneath the spool holder that I've been using for awhile now. This one, which is great.
It's a simple design, with 3mm holes for basic computer type screws (don't want the kids getting into it without a screw driver). Tested and working well.

title: The Great Red Dragon and the Woman Clothed in Sun by William Blake

description.text:

Each toy line has its own unique peg. Follow the PDF instructions to find out which peg stand works with your toy line.

P.S. We are starting a Kickstarter for this product. Get hundreds of Peg stands for cheap. If you provide your email on our website we will send your an email message letting you know when the Kickstarter begins. Use the link below.

http://www.ablegames.win/kickstarter.htm

Figures you can peg - Almost all but specifically StarWars, Heman, Gundam, Marvel, Lego, DC, Barbie, HotWheels, Transformers, Pokemon.

Gundam Peg - Go to the Montreal Gunpla Club facebook group to get 3 more attachments for larger Gundam including a heavy duty MG peg.

Okay.. you like the Pegs and can use them to display your collection but you don't have a 3D printer or your 3D printer will take a year to print all the pegs you need. NOT A PROBLEM.... Thats why we want to create the Kickstarter so that we all have top quality pegs, as many as we want for an affordable price. author: verkoren

description.text: body parts

A very simple chess set I designed after Pagan/Norse symbology. Pieces are all just shy of 50mm tall (Except the pawn, which is shorter), and 30mm in diameter at the base, so they should be compatible with most chess boards.

The symbols I used on each piece are; Knight (Valknut), Bishop (Pentacle), Queen (Yggdrasil), Rook (Wheel of the Year), King (Mjolnir). The Pawn was left blank. I marked all major pieces with their "chess" name on the back side so you can tell what is what without turning it.

I suggest printing with no larger than 0.1 layers due to the narrow lines in the pentacle.

The board prints as follows: 1 of each corner ("corn1" and "corn3" in one color, "corn2" and "corn4" in the other), 12 of each edge (6 of each color), and 36 of the core (18 of each color)...

description.text:
I'm sharing my current LED / Arduino / Neopixel Nerf Barrel project while it's still in process. The 3D printed barrel is quite usable as-is, and fits any modulus / stryfe barrel.

You will see the design is complete and I have prototyped it to get it working, however a couple damaged neopixels is causing me some assembly rework. I decided to publish before I loose steam.

The bill of materials beyond the 3D printed barrel is below:
1x round (18.3mm hole) rocker switch
1x arduino pro mini or equivalent (5v logic version)
1x 470ohm resistor
1x 10microF capacitor
13x 5mm X 5mm surface mount neopixels
1x 9v battery
1x 5vdc regulator

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100% on battery door and 30% on barrel

Notes:

i had good results printing the barrel sticking up from the bed (180mm z height), and printing the battery door on its exterior face.

For the battery door, the battery clasp mis-printed until I added a 6-wide brim 1-layer high.

1) Clean-up

1 - snap off the barrel support structure from the end that connects to the nerf blaster.
2 - clean up your supports from inside the battery/electronics compartment.
3 - clean up brim from the battery door

2) Assemble electronics

1 - connect the 9v battery to the 5v regulator
2 - connect the toggle switch in series with the power
3 - solder together the neopixel string at 22mm spacing (outside to outside of the 5mm square neopixels)
4 - install a 470ohm resistor on pin 6 of the arduino and attach the data-in line from your neopixels
5 - install a 10microF capacitor across the +/- leads that supply power to the neopixels. for this short run, I power them off the same power rails that provide 5v to the arduino.
6 - snap in the 5mm neopixels into the holes in the barrel.

3) program the arduino

I will share an final code that has the LED patters programed later, but this starter code will get you going. Remember to update the NUMPIXELS variable.

// NeoPixel Ring simple sketch (c) 2013 Shae Erisson
// released under the GPLv3 license to match the rest of the AdaFruit NeoPixel library

#include <Adafruit_NeoPixel.h>
#ifdef __AVR__
  #include <avr/power.h>
#endif

// Which pin on the Arduino is connected to the NeoPixels?
// On a Trinket or Gemma we suggest changing this to 1
#define PIN            6

// How many NeoPixels are attached to the Arduino?
#define NUMPIXELS      13

// When we setup the NeoPixel library, we tell it how many pixels, and which pin to use to send signals.
// Note that for older NeoPixel strips you might need to change the third parameter--see the strandtest
// example for more information on possible values.
Adafruit_NeoPixel pixels = Adafruit_NeoPixel(NUMPIXELS, PIN, NEO_GRB + NEO_KHZ800);

int delayval = 20; // delay for half a second
int peakval = 25; // set peak color value for fade
void setup() {

  pixels.begin(); // This initializes the NeoPixel library.
}

void loop() {

  // fader routine (red)
  for(int i=0;i<peakval;i++){

      pixels.setPixelColor(0, pixels.Color(i,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(1, pixels.Color(i,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(2, pixels.Color(i,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(3, pixels.Color(i,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(4, pixels.Color(i,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(5, pixels.Color(i,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(6, pixels.Color(i,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(7, pixels.Color(i,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(8, pixels.Color(i,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(9, pixels.Color(i,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(10, pixels.Color(i,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(11, pixels.Color(i,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(12, pixels.Color(i,0,0)); 

      pixels.show(); // This sends the updated pixel color to the hardware.
      delay(delayval); // Delay for a period of time (in milliseconds).

  }

  for(int i=0;i<peakval;i++){

      pixels.setPixelColor(0, pixels.Color(peakval-i-1,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(1, pixels.Color(peakval-i-1,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(2, pixels.Color(peakval-i-1,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(3, pixels.Color(peakval-i-1,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(4, pixels.Color(peakval-i-1,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(5, pixels.Color(peakval-i-1,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(6, pixels.Color(peakval-i-1,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(7, pixels.Color(peakval-i-1,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(8, pixels.Color(peakval-i-1,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(9, pixels.Color(peakval-i-1,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(10, pixels.Color(peakval-i-1,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(11, pixels.Color(peakval-i-1,0,0)); 
      pixels.setPixelColor(12, pixels.Color(peakval-i-1,0,0)); 

      pixels.show(); // This sends the updated pixel color to the hardware.
      delay(delayval); // Delay for a period of time (in milliseconds).

  }

  delay(500); // pause dark before relooping
}

title: Compressed air turbine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple turbine for compressed air for experimentation. :-)

I have made two models.
The first one you can see on the pictures.
The axel is a 10mm diameter metal rod I turned down to 8mm on a lathe.
But you can something else as an axel, for instance threated rod 8mm.
For bearings this turbine has the 608Z (diameter 22mm,hole 8mm& thickness 7mm).
For assembly see pictures.

It works very well and runs very fast, but at 8bar of pressure the air pushes the grease out of the bearings.
Also it’s very important that the housing is fitted together very tight,
otherwise the air will escape all over the place :-)

printed in PET-G res. 0.2mm

print_settings.Notes:: To assemble these, the 1.5mm magnet is pushed down below the surface so the pin just has plastic contact and a weak hold for small notes and so on.  Then I also got some 6mm x 3mm magnets and with those they stick out a little bit but not a lot so you get a much stronger hold to hold larger things due to direct magnet contact.  I found it useful to have some sort of clamp or weight push down on the magnet as my 5-minute epoxy sets so the pin will sit flat on the final usage and not be tilted due to magnet poking out a little bit.

description.text:
This is the body for a magnetic pin or tac suitable for holding notes on metal things like the kitchen fridge or a file cabinet and so on.

Kind of silly little thing as you can get assembled ones for around 50 cents but I was in a situation I needed a few and already had the 6mm x 1.5mm rare earth magnets so what the heck, it was done on Fusion 360. For a stronger hold where the magnet will be in direct contact with metal I use 6mm x 3mm magnets also very cheap with free shipment on EBay.

The price in bulk for 6mm x 1.5mm (about 1/4" x 1/8") rare earth magnets is trending now on ebay for 50 magnets with free shipping for about $8 so these are actually cheaper if you have spare time to make and print them.

Suggest you duplicate the part as you do the slicer perhaps 4-8 times and make one print for many parts in the usual way of letting it run for a few hours.

There is an assembly step to put the magnet into the hole in the bottom with some silicon type glue or even epoxy and push it in so it is below the plastic so the pin sits flat.

To make these look good a very nice resolution printer with 0.4mm nozzle and print the outer layer slow such as 15mm/sec.

If your printer does not form a hole that is quite large enough hand hold a 1/4" drill and ream it out a little for better magnet fit.

For really small 'gratuities' since thingiverse does a huge $3 or more for paypal (too much IMHO) you may use bitcoin address 1yKJcrkLE7RmsLmZPL3ku5PpazGzNmDSS or Ethereum address 0xbCCEf017Ff00215496A768fb0238893Edf7584B0 but no worries or expectations, key thing is you find this useful!

Most important thing is you have fun and enjoy this if it is useful to you!
Mark

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Duplicator 6

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.4mm nozzle is best

35%

Notes:

To make these look good a very nice resolution printer with 0.4mm nozzle and print the outer layer slow such as 15mm/sec.

If your printer does not form a hole that is quite large enough hand hold a 1/4" drill and ream it out a little for better magnet fit.

To assemble these, the 1.5mm magnet is pushed down below the surface so the pin just has plastic contact and a weak hold for small notes and so on. Then I also got some 6mm x 3mm magnets and with those they stick out a little bit but not a lot so you get a much stronger hold to hold larger things due to direct magnet contact. I found it useful to have some sort of clamp or weight push down on the magnet as my 5-minute epoxy sets so the pin will sit flat on the final usage and not be tilted due to magnet poking out a little bit.

description.text:
This is a reupload of some files that I got late Dec. of 2016. Someone asked about sharing them and initially I was hesitant to do so. After a lot of thought, I decided to reupload them under the original license, with the original files as I received them. They were distributed for free under a Creative Commons attribution, non-commercial, non-derivatives license. I obtained them on the date and time in the second picture.

I am hereby giving attribution for these files by including the original attribution files multiple times and proclaiming here that I am not the original maker of these files. That is a gentleman by the name of Spring_Melt here on Thingiverse, or Paul Myers on Youtube. The credit goes to him.

I also won't be making any monetary gain from this upload nor have I uploaded them in a modified form. They are original and complete to the date that I got them, and once again, under the same license I obtained them.

https://web.archive.org/web/20170302231035/www.thingiverse.com/thing:1942755

Original files located in the .zip

That all being said, I don't think people should do drugs, drugs make you lame.
I am not a doctor, results may vary.

Update: I've recently found that this device can be used as a wine aerator by taking the moving part out and stuffing it up the out hole, giving a gentle twist to keep it in position. Possibly better for wines than metal, depends on taste of course, like caviar and metal spoons.

Update 2: The original is back up, I would suggest going to take a look at it and giving the creator a nice word for his brain-child. He has a few noteworthy designs.

Update 3: The original is down again and user has been deleted. Seems he's begging on patreon now and has developed a fur coat habit. -_- Don't do drugs kids, you'll be wearing women's clothing before too long.

title: Cheap and Easy Filament Out Sensor box

description.text:
Running out of filament in the middle of a print is annoying, especially when you are not around. This design will detect the filament out condition and pause the print for you to change filament. The whole implementation costs you next to nothing, assume you already use the Raspberry Pi and Octoprint to print your project.

Hardware:

  • A tact switch KW11-3Z 5A 250V micro switch 3Pin and two wires to the Raspberry Pi.

Wiring:

  • Solder the first wire to COM pin (marked with letter C) on the switch, this will be the ground wire to the Raspberry Pi.
  • Solder the second wire to the NO pin in the middle of the switch. This is the Normally Open pin and will connect to one of the GPIO pin on the Raspberry Pi.
    I reused the wires off my old earphone that I no longer need. You can probably use 22gauge wires for this project. Make sure it's long enough to get to the Raspberry Pi with wire left to move around.

Assembly:

  • Pick out the location where you want to place the filament Sensor box and print the correct L2R or R2L box to select the filament moving from left to right or right to left of the box. It has the arrow direction to help you identify its direction too. Next is to choose the adapter (clip or x-carriage) and secure the box to the adapter.
  • If you choose the x-carriage adapter as shown in the picture, you need the R2L type of box which will eventually make the filament going top down since it will be attached sideway to the x-carriage adapter. You can now go to the testing and installing software steps.

Testing at system level to make sure your wiring is good:

  • In fact, you can use this step to test out the switch function even before printing anything out, just connect the switch's wire to the Raspberry Pi's ground and GPIO pin you want to use for this project.
  • The X-carriage installation is used as example but the clip type is similar. First attach the R2L box to the X-carriage adapter using 2 x M3 screws and 2 nuts, then secure the adapter/box assembly to the X-carriage using the existing screws as shown in the picture.
    You can now run the stop switch's wires through the sensor box large hole to the Raspberry Pi. The COM wire goes to ground, the NO (Normally Open) goes to GPIO. For the Raspberry PI rev 2, the ground is pin header 9 and this example uses BCM GPIO 17, which is pin header 11. Note that this GPIO-17 is actually GPIO-0 when using wiringpi to test in this step. Next is to place the switch in correct position or else you will run into issue when pushing the filament into the box. For R2L box, the switch is placed with the open tab on the left and the ground wire on the right side (see the first picture). It’s reverse for the L2R box, i.e. the ground wire on the left side. Once done, snap the lid in the correct way to remind you which direction the filament will go (second picture).
  • Connect to the Raspberry Pi using SSH, username pi. Enter the following two commands to check the GPIO-0 in wiring pi mode (or your own GPIO wiring pi pin number):
    gpio mode 0 up
    gpio read 0
    It should return the value 1 (high) to indicate there is no filament. Now cut a piece of filament and push through the hole and see it come out the other side. Repeat the second command (gpio read 0), this time it will report the value 0 (low). If you get to this point, you are done with the hardware installation. Go on to the software installation.

Software Installation:

  • Using the browser from another system, connect to the Octopi via http.
  • Click on the Setting icon (the wrench logo at the top right). Select Plugin Manager.
  • In the Plugin Manager screen, you should see the “Get More…” long button at the bottom, click that.
  • One the next screen, use the scroll bar to scroll down until you see “Filament Sensor Reloaded”. Click Install button next to that and let it complete the installation. Click Close when done.
  • REBOOT the Raspberry Pi to activate the software.
  • Proceed to the Software Configuration.

Software Configuration:

  • Once the Raspberry Pi is back, use the Browser to go OctoPrint Settings screen. This time you should see the “Filament Sensor Reloaded” under “PLUGINS”, click that link.
  • Enter 17 for Pin. Or another GPIO BCM pin you prefer.
  • Debounce Time should be default to 250ms. If not, type 250.
  • Switch Type should be default to Normally Open. If not, select it from the list by clicking on the up/down arrows at the end of the list.
  • Board Pin Mode - select BCM Mode.
  • Out of filament GCODE,enter the following lines (or copy/paste)
    ;pause
    M600
  • Make sure the selection box for “Pause print when out of filament” is checked. Click Save button at the bottom right to complete the configuration. Next is the Configuration after clicking Resume steps.

Configuration GCODE scripts:

  • Go back to the Settings screen, this time click on the “GCODE Scripts” on the left side under “PRINTER”.

  • In the edit box for "After print job is paused", add the following lines:
    G60 S0 ; save current position to S0
    G91 ; set to relative positioning
    G1 E-1 F300 ;retract the filament a bit before lifting the nozzle, to release some of the pressure
    G1 Z+2 F{travel_speed} ;move Z up a bit
    G28 X0 ;move X to min endstops, so the head is out of the way
    M104 S0 ;extruder heater off
    M140 S0 ;heated bed heater off (if you have it)
    M84 ; disable motors
    ;Put printing message on LCD screen
    M117 Change Filament

  • In the edit box for “Before print job is resumed”, enter the following lines:
    G90 ; set to absolute positioning
    G61 S0 ; restore position

  • Now you are really done with configuration, click Save
  • Move to the real test, you can do it as many times as you like to be sure the sensor switch is functioning properly.

The Real Test:

  • Run the filament through the box and to the extruder. My trick to always get the filament through is to heat the extruder to 200deg, then pull the old filament out. Do not cut the filament like a lot of people suggested, you need the extruder tube to be empty and pulling the filament out is the only way. If you get into the situation of having some filament stuck in the tube, the best way is to use a long thin hex Allen key and push the filament down. If you resource to Allen key to push old filament out and using the X-carriage adapter, you can remove the left screw of the adapter, rotate the sensor box clockwise to have room to work. Before pushing the new filament in you want to cut it diagonally such that its tip is as sharp as a needle, with the sharp tip you can be sure that it will go through the tube easily. The printer should be ready to print by now.
  • Start to print a test 20mm test cube, when it just started snip the filament above the sensor box (Not under the box) and see it slowly gone down the hole. The second picture actually shows the filament being cut before the print was started. When you hear the clicking sound from the sensor switch, the printer should also detect filament out condition and move the extruder head to the left and display "Change Filament".
  • At this point the motor is disabled and all heaters are off waiting for you to come to its rescue. I assume that you are normally not there next to the printer when the filament run out, this is a safety feature you might want to keep.
  • You need to go to the Octoprint's Temperature tab to manually heat the extruder hotend up to 200deg, heat bed to 60 deg (or the heat settings you desire).
  • Once the extruder temperature is reached, pull the old filament out and push the new filament through the box and into the hotend hole.
  • Click Resume to see the printer goes back to the old position and continue the print. The good part of this little Filament Sensor design is mostly for peace of mind, you don't want to have a 10 hours left of printing of the air with the hotend & heat bed still fuming at high temperature. Saving the print is also nice too.

I also uploaded my setup for other GCODE scripts from Octoprint in case you are interested.

Note: I provide the clip type of adapter so you can install the filament sensor box at various location but I did not try it out yet. The clip adapter lets you attach the box vertically or horizontally (two flavors), and each clip adapter allows the box to attach in two different directions.
If you choose to design a new type of adapter then make sure to have two holes with 1.75mm radius spaced 14mm apart, the two holes within the R2L or L2R boxes are 3.75mm from the edges.

Update 1: Added the improved top that presses the switch firmly inside. Also add a little side gap on the top to make its removal easier

Update 2: Added note about new pause scripts to resume at the same spot. It did not resume at the same spot earlier, hit & miss. The major change is the pause script section is moved to GCODE Script "After print job is paused". Refer to fun Snap Cubes thingi https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2560893 to see photos of my Filament Out condition tests.

title: Quadcopter Landing Gear (also some motor soft mounting)

description.text:
I designed this object because I had problems with the props hitting the ground at takeoff, since a under sling battery. The object also might help to reduce some vibrations.

It will lift the end of your quad arms by 12mm, which is 2mm more than most neoprene/3m pads. Make sure to not tighten the motor screws too hard.

My succession is, to print this in TPU to not destroy it on a hard landing.

title: Porter Cable Scroll Saw Throat Plate

description.text:
This is an improved version of the throat plate for the porter cable scroll saw. The original black throat plate came with the scroll saw was about 1mm lower than the table, so as I cut through a wood piece, it stuck at the edge of the hole. Also, because of the space between wood and the plate, I experienced huge vibration. So it was very hard to use the scroll saw and I ended up with giving up using it.

This throat plate will solve those issues and it becomes very easy to use because there is no space between the hole and the plate and also the plate will be flush to the table, so there will be no vibration or stuck. I also designed it stronger than the original by making it thicker and also added extra bone structure behind the plate.

It should snap in and both diameter and the height should be perfectly match to the table saw table, but it could be slightly higher than the table. In that case, sand it down on the table until it becomes flush to the table.

description.text:
This is my attempt at a cheap and easy dual Z mod for the CR-10. I have not tried this yet, I'm waiting for my lead screw.

My BOM

1 x 608 ball bearing (top lead screw mount)
2 x 625 ball bearing (bottom lead screw mount)
1 x 5 to 8mm flex coupling.
1 x m5 20mm bolt (bottom mount to secure coupler to bearings)
1 x m5 nut (see above)
3 x m5 50mm bolts, 40mm would probably work too (X gantry plate)
1 x 500mm lead screw (best option might be 2 x 600mm. Thus way you kan keep full z height)
1 x lead screw nut
1 x GT2 belt. (I could not find a closed loop in the right lenght so I just spliced my own, more info below)

I'm using gantry plate from this model https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2335916.

Belt splicing jig and info.https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1827260. I ended up just using flexible super glue and no pins and it seems to be strong enough,

If i forgot something leave a comment and I'll try to fix it.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,24

Infill:

25

Notes:

I printed in the orientation the files are and used support only on the bottom mount.

comments.text: The gantry plate you're using from the skookum brace doesn't include a larger hole on the inside screw hole of the gantry plate does it?  That is the screw that has the eccentric adjustment and it seems like not having an equivalent adjustment on both plates could cause some mis-alignment of the wheels axle and therefore cause unwanted wear. You may want to consider remixing that plate and enlarging the hole and using an eccentric spacer for the back side additions.

title: X Axis Idler Mount With Tensioner Ver.2 (K8200 / 3DRAG)

description.text:
This my second version of the X-axis idler-pulley-mounting, with a belt tensioner added. This device allows moving the idler in all directions you need. In addition, it is thereby also possible to use different pulley sizes.
It works fine together with my X-axis motor-mount which can be found here (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:253741). This accessory is the preparation for the update of the Y-axis to GT2 belt transmission.
Info: There´re two versions of the outrigger.
-one with my own support for overhanging areas
-one without support - it´s your choice

You need:
8x M5x16 bolts
9x M5 nuts
1x M5x30 bolt (best stainless steel)
2x M3 bolts with nuts
2x M5 washer
2x 625 bearings
pulley with 5mm axis diameter Push the M3 nut in the idler-outrigger and screw in the M3 bolt first. Then plug the inlay on the M3 bolt before you insert the ball bearings. Use the long M5 bolt as axis for your pulley mounted between the bearings. For more information, take a look on the 3D image

comments.text: You hav to change the x-axis Steps/mm in your Firmware. Use Repetier-Host calculator (under tools) for calculating pulley parameter for your firmware. The bearings are closed (ZZ) 625 er

author: HEJHEJ

description.text:
Obviously not liking the small corner supports used for the Tronxy X3A, specifically for the Z-axis I designed bracket from scratch.

IMPORTANT NOTE: After publishing here and then fitting I saw that the guide blocks closest to the 3 holes which also help to strengthen the structure are about 2mm too long towards the holes. Thus if you want to use the holes for T-Nut assembly you will need to cut-off about 2mm to accommodate turning of the T-nuts. By then I`ve upgraded the design to a very strong and rigid design which is also uploaded here and called "Monster". In the "Monster" the guides have been shortened to easily accommodate the T-nuts.
